description: 15th century, learned borrowing from Latin attritio (“a rubbing against”), from the verb attritus, past participle of atterere (“to wear”), from ad- (“to, towards”) +‎ terere (“to rub”).

entries.meaning: Grinding down or wearing away by friction.
The gradual reduction in a tangible or intangible resource due to causes that are passive and do not involve productive use of the resource.
(human resources) A gradual, natural reduction in membership or personnel, as through retirement, resignation, or death.
(sciences) The loss of participants during an experiment.
(dentistry) The wearing of teeth due to their grinding.
(linguistics) The loss of a first or second language or a portion of that language.

verbs.description: attrition (third-person singular simple present attritions, present participle attritioning, simple past and past participle attritioned)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To grind or wear down through friction.
(transitive) To reduce the number of (jobs or workers) by not hiring new employees to fill positions that become vacant (often with out).
examples: […]  but the heart of the health services in New York will have to attrition out some 3,000 to 5,000 jobs.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To undergo a reduction in number.
examples: The cohort of one hundred students had attritioned to sixty by the end of secondary school.
